description_new: 2019 photograph with the Teaching and Learning Center on the left, Brink Hall on the right, and two University vehicles parked between the buildings above the stairs.
narrative: The University of Idaho has undergone significant changes since its establishment at the very end of the 1800s, many of which include the addition of new buildings, roads, and infrastructure. Brink hall acts as a familiar landmark in these photos, but the change depicted in these images is apparent. The photo from the 1940s shows Brink Hall to the right with the University Farms in the background. Now the view from this location includes new infrastructure including a part of the Idaho Commons and concrete stairs surrounded by foliage that lead to even more new campus buildings such as the library, the Agricultural Science building, and the Integrated Research and Innovation Center.
instagram_text: Something seems different- the TLC and Commons are gone! Prior to the building of the Commons and TLC and surrounding construction, this campus location provided an excellent view of the university farms. Do you notice anything familiar? Phinney-Brink Hall was already built at this time.
hashtags: University of Idaho; Uidaho; Phinney Hall; Brink Hall; University Farms; Then and Now; Past and Present; classic cars; black and white

title: Administration Building, University of Idaho (1892-1906). [51-6]
collection: University of Idaho Campus Photographs
description_old: 1899 photograph of Administration Building.  View of the drive up to the old Administration.   [PG1_51-06]
subject: Administration building
publisher - digital: University of Idaho Library Digital Initiatives, http://www.lib.uidaho.edu/digital/
source: PG 1, University of Idaho Campus Photographs, University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives, http://www.lib.uidaho.edu/special-collections/
rights: Material determined to be in Public Domain based on date of publication. Material made available by the University of Idaho Library. For more information, please contact University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives Department at libspec@uidaho.edu.
ordering information: To order a reproduction, inquire about permissions, or for information about prices email libspec@uidaho.edu
format original: 4x5 black and white glass negative, 8x10 print
description_new: 2019 photograph of the new Administration Building and the drive up to it.
narrative: The Administration Building has been an icon of the University of Idaho over more than a century despite dramatic changes. Built in 1892, the Old Administration building was constructed of red brick into a "U" shape consisting of a main section and east and west wings. This historic building stood until a fire destroyed it in 1906 and construction of the New Administration Building began the next year. The New Administration Builidng bears similarities to its predecessor, such as its red brick exterior and U shape, however the new building exhibits new features such as the clock tower, stained glass windows, an auditorium, and other updated infrastructure.
instagram_text: Did you know that the current Administration Building is not the original? The old Administration Building was built in 1891 and housed classrooms, the library, and other offices. It was considered to be "the most attractive building in Idaho" until a fire destroyed it in 1906. Bits of rubble were gathered to create the aptly named Memorial Steps, and in 1907 construction of our current Administration Building was underway!
hashtags: University of Idaho; Administration building; Uidaho; then and now; past and present; black and white

narrative: The Administration Building has been an icon of the University of Idaho over more than a century despite dramatic changes. Built in 1892, the Old Administration building was constructed of red brick into a "U" shape consisting of a main section and east and west wings. The New Administration Builidng bears similarities to its predecessor, such as its red brick exterior and U shape, however the new building exhibits new features such as the clock tower, stained glass windows, an auditorium, and other updated infrastructure.
instagram_text: The Administration Building has never looked better, especially compared to the old Administration Building after a fire destroyed it in 1906. The old Admin was reduced to rubble and construction of the current Admin was well underway in 1907!

title: Memorial Gymnasium, University of Idaho. Construction. [61-3]
collection: University of Idaho Campus Photographs
description_old: 1928 photograph of Memorial Gymnasium.  View of construction.  [PG1_61-03]
subject: Construction
publisher - digital: University of Idaho Library Digital Initiatives, http://www.lib.uidaho.edu/digital/
source: PG 1, University of Idaho Campus Photographs, University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives, http://www.lib.uidaho.edu/special-collections/
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes. Digital reproduction rights granted by University of Idaho Library. For other uses beyond educational use, please contact University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives Department at libspec@uidaho.edu.
ordering information: To order a reproduction, inquire about permissions, or for information about prices email libspec@uidaho.edu
description_new: 2019 photograph of the Memorial Gym.
narrative: "Commonly known as "Mem Gym", the Memorial Gymnasium was built in 1929 as a memorial to all Idahoans who lost their lives in World War 1. The building was designed by UI faculty members and features many architectural quirks such as the leatherhead-footballer gargoyles that decorate its walls and windows. It has served as a sports area and physical education venue seating 2,500 as well as for UI commencements and events. First Lady Eleanor Roosevelt gave a lecture in the main gymnasium in 1938, which is one of many reasons that the building was added to the National Register of Historic Places at the relatively young age of 49 years in 1977." This building's function has shifted with the University's changing and growing campus, however it remains a beautiful and historic icon of the University.
instagram_text: Memorial gym houses more than just sports- it is home to amazing history! Since its construction in 1929, this building has featured sporting events, physical education classes, commencements, a lecture by First Lady Eleanor Roosevelt, and was even added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1977. It also is the home to some leatherhead-footballer gargoyles!
hashtags: University of Idaho; Uidaho; Memorial Gym; construction; then and now; past and present; black and white

narrative: After the fire of 1906 destroyed the old Administration Building, only a skeleton of the building remained. Many stones from the rubble were collected and constructed into Memorial steps, which serve as a tribute to the University's historic past.
instagram_text: Fashion may have changed since the 1950s but the Memorial Steps haven't! These historic steps were constructed from the rubble of the Old Adminstration building which was destroyed by a fire in 1906. Hence the name, these steps now serve as a memorial to the University's history.

In 1966 a president's residence was under construction now, in 2019, a new president's residence has been built. The new 6,000 square foot building sits on top of the same foundation as the old president's house, keeping the history alive.
instagram_text: The "I Tower" hasn't changed but the President's residence sure has! This photo of the President's residence in 1966 looks much different than the modern home built in 2019.

description_new: 2019 photograph of the University Power Plant with construction in the background.
narrative: Built in 1927 at a cost of 75,000 dollars, the power and heating plant has been and remains critical to the function of the University of Idaho. This four story building is made of brick and concrete and has a flat roof of composition roofing. This building has undergone minimal changes including boilers added in 1939 and 1948. This building is home to a lot of history as well as a couple friendly decorative skeletons in the window who are always dressed for the season.
instagram_text: Can you spot the differences? Since its construction in 1926 the University of Idaho power plant has undergone a few dramatic changes such as the removal of the smokestack. Though you may not spot any classic cars anymore, a glance through the window may show some friendly decorative skeletons dressed for the season!
hashtags: University of Idaho; Uidaho; Power Plant; classic cars; black and white; Steam Plant; Then and Now; Past and Present

Though commencement ceremonies are no longer held here, the Memorial Gym's functions have been shifted to accomodates the University's needs while remaining a beautiful and historic landmark of the University of Idaho.
instagram_text: You may not see many classic cars driving around Memorial Gym anymore but there is history in the building itself! Did you know that this building was built as a memorial to Idahoans lost in World War 1 and that it was added to the National Register of Historic Places? For almost 100 years this building has been the venue for many university events.

description_new: 2019 photo of the Pi Kappa Phi fraternity on the northwest corner of Deakin and Idaho Streets.
narrative: After receiving its charter in 1925, construction of the Alpha Tau Omega fraternity house was completed in 1928. After eighty years on the University of Idaho campus the Alpha Tau Omega fraternity left its house in the Fall of 2012 due to a significant loss of members. The following year the men of Pi Kappa Phi fraternity leased this house and have occupied it since then.
instagram_text: Built in 1928, this building was orginally the Alpha Tao Omega fraternity house. 85 years later in 2013 this became the home to the men of Pi Kappa Phi fraternity. Pi Kappa Phi seeks to develop leaders and encourage service, and luckily they have a beautiful and historic house to do it in!
hashtags: University of Idaho; UIdaho; Greek life; Idaho Greek life; Alpha Tao Omega; Pi Kappa Phi; Pi Kapp; Pi Kappa Phi Kappa Iota Chapter; Fraternity House; Construction; Then and Now; Past and Present; Black and White

description_new: 2019 photograph of Pi Kappa Alpha fraternity house on the southeast corner of University and Elm Streets.
narrative: This house was originally the residence of the men of Delta Chi fraternity who left campus in 2012. From 2012 to the Spring of 2019 this building was home to the women of Steel House, which is an on-campus cooperative living group for women. Now, as of Summer of 2019, this building is home to the men of Pi Kappa Alpha fraternity.
instagram_text: Originally the Delta Chi fraternity house, this building has undergone several resident turnovers! From 2012 to 2018 this house belonged to the Steelhouse women's living and as of 2019 will be the Pi Kappa Alpha fraternity house. Pi Kappa Apha is dedicated to developing men of integrity, intellect, and high moral character and to fostering a truly lifelong fraternal experience Welcome to campus!

description_new: 2019 photo of the Delta Gamma sorority house on the northeast corner of Idaho and Elm Streets.
narrative: The Nu chapter of Delta Gamma sorority was founded in 1911, making it one of the oldest sororities on the University of Idaho campus, and in 1914 the women of Delta Gamma moved into their new sorority house. Many years later in 1984 their sorority house was remodelled to include nine new study rooms, new bathrooms, more sleeping space, and more lounging room to accommodate their growing membership.
instagram_text: Delta Gamma sorority was founded in 1911, making it one of the oldest sororities on the University of Idaho campus. Though some changes were made to the house to accommodate growing membership, the original foundation, shape, chimney, and other features can still be seen. Check out the Delta Gamma anchor next time you go by!

narrative: In 1910 Gamma Phi Beta sorority officially became the first national sorority to join the University of Idaho. This house was used by Gamma Phi Beta between the years of 1917 and 1958 before this sorority moved elsewhere. Their current sorority house is located at 709 Elm Street and can be recognized by it’s pink hue.
instagram_text: The Gamma Phi Beta sorority house has changed quite a bit since this photo was taken in the 1930s, don't you think? In 1910 Gamma Phi Beta officially became the first national sorority to join the University of Idaho.

narrative: Located on the corner of University and Deakin Avenues is a building that looks like a castle. Built in 1926, this building was originally home to the women of Kappa Alpha Theta sorority until they moved to a new house in 1969. That same year the men of Delta Sigma Phi fraternity moved in and have lived there ever since.
instagram_text: Have you seen the castle on campus? It actually used to be the Kappa Alpha Theta sorority house and is currently the Delta Sigma Phi fraternity house!

collection: University of Idaho Student Organizations Collection (PG2)

description_new: 2019 photograph of the Kappa Sigma fraternity house on the northeast corner of Blake and Sweet Avenues.
narrative: Established in 1905, the Kappa Sigma fraternity was the first national fraternity at the University of Idaho and their fraternity house, which was built in 1916, has been continuously occupied by the men of this organization since it's construction. This building was finally recognized and added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1996.
instagram_text: Greek life is very prominent at the University of Idaho, but did you know that Kappa Sigma Fraternity was the first Greek organization on campus? Shortly after their arrival to UI in 1905 construction of their fraternity house began and was completed in 1916. Now there are a total of 16 fraternities, 10 sororities, and 7 multicultural Greek organizations on our campus.
hashtags: University of Idaho; Uidaho; Greek life; Idaho Greek life; Kappa Sigma Fraternity; KSig; Kappa Simga Gamma Theta Chapter; Then and now; past and present; black and white; Fraternity House

description_new: 2019 photo of the Lambda Chi Alpha fraternity house located on the northeast corner of College and Deakin Avenues
narrative: This building has been home to a number of Greek organizations since its construction in the 1926, but its primary resident has been Lamda Chi Alpha fraternity. The University of Idaho chapter of Lambda Chi Alpha was established in 1927 but was closed between the years of 1946 and 1958, and again from 1985 to 1990. During the house's vacant periods Pi Beta Phi sorority and Alpha Gamma Rho fraternity took residence in the building.
instagram_text: The Lambda Chi Alpha fraternity house has had a lot of turnover! Pi Beta Phi sorority used to occupy this house as did the Alpha Gamma Rho fraternity until Lambda Chi Alpha returned in 2008.

description_new: 2019 angled photo of the Phi Kappa Tau fraternity house, located at 620 Idaho Avenue on the University of Idaho campus.
narrative: In 1924 the Gamma Eta chapter of Sigma Chi was established and their fraternity house was built. Sigma Chi eventually moved to their current residence on Nez Perce Drive and the house was later occupied by Pi Beta Phi sorority and eventually Steelhouse women's living between 2009-2012. Phi Kappa Tau fraternity has occupied this residence off and on since it's construction and are the current residents.
instagram_text: Built in 1924, this house has been the home to members of Sigma Chi fraternity, Pi Beta Phi sorority, Steelhouse women's living, and is currently the Phi Kappa Tau fraternity house.

source: PG2 University of Idaho Student Organizations Collection

description_new: 2019 photo of the entrance to the Phi Gamma Delta fraternity house.
narrative: The University of Idaho chapter of Phi Gamma Delta fraternity, also known as FIJI, was established in 1920 and was followed by the construction of their fraternity house in 1926. Taken in the 1940s, this photo shows the men of Phi Gamma Delta during a time when many fraternities were disbanded due to World War II. Despite many wars and setbacks between their founding and now, the University of Idaho Phi Gamma Delta is currently the second oldest continuously operating chapter of this fraternity on the West Coast. Since its construction the fraternity house has undergone many changes including the addition of a new wing and indoor remodelling.
instagram_text: Don't be fooled by the seemingly unchanged exterior of the Phi Gamma Delta fraternity house- it has undergone remodelling and additions since being built in 1926. Though their house and and fashion choices have changed, their values of friendship, knowledge, service, morality, and excellence have not!
hashtags: University of Idaho; Uidaho; Greek Life; Idaho Greek life; FIJI; Phi Gamma Delta; FIJI Men; Phi Gamma Delta Mu Iota Chapter; Phi Gamma Delta Fraternity; Fraternity House; Then and Now; Black and White; Past and Present
